@calmh will have to look at this, he's got better grips of this.

I'm seeing this exact same behavior -- I have 3 local nodes and 1 remote. The remote node is always connected to the local ones but the local ones will remain disconnected from each other once the initial connection fails.
I assume it fixes itself after restarting?
Correct, I had a quick look at the code and it looks like sendLocalAnnouncement is only called once but hopefully I can dig into it again this evening.
That's a for loop that never stops, so it's not it.

So it seems to be caused by v6 discovery now, which I think you can just disable for now.
Basically the beacon.go needs to be converted into a suture service like broadcast.go, or atleast we need to add a write timeout.
Just disable it by removing the udp6:// line from the discovery server address?
No, set the localAnnounceMCAddr in the config to nothing.
That seems to have done the trick so far in my very limited testing. I'll test it some more in a bit.

Confirmed, after setting localAnnounceMCAddr to nothing, it works for me, too (at least my little test case). Will try my main use case.

Syncthing 0.11.13
After 36h uptime, the server device is still conscious and approachable. As I'm not (yet) into this IPv6 business, this workaround is fine for me.

issue.title: New global discovery protocol over HTTPS (fixes #628)

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New features or improvements of some kind, as opposed to a problem (bug)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
This is going to be one of those where it really sucks to be the reviewer, sorry. Everything kind of tied into each other so there's a lot of changes where it doesn't make sense to break them out into separate pull requests... :/ Not done yet, just for visibility. The things happening in this branch so far are:
- Rewrite the multicast and broadcast beacons to be actual suture.Services with full internal retry forever, and exposing an `Error() error` to the outside to check on their status.
- Rewrite the local broadcast thing to be separate services for ipv4 broadcast and ipv6 multicasts. It's actually the same code, it just switches out the beacon used based on the format of the address parameter. The discovery service also is a Service supports the same Error() method for inspection from the outside.
- Lots of code removed from the discovery package as there is no global discovery over udp, so the code sharing and factories depending on the udp4:// etc schema are gone.
- A new global discovery thing over HTTPS
- A new caching discovery mux that collects all of these (x \* global discovery services, ipv4 local, ipv6 local) and presents a single interface to the outside, with Lookup() and child status methods.
- Some changes in the relay service to easier expose status of the various relays without having to depend on the package for the returned data types and so on.

To maybe review this somewhat, I'd suggest 
1. starting by looking at the new startup wiring in syncthingMain()
2.  then looking at the machinery in discovery/discovery.go and the corresponding discovery/{local,global}.go files
3. then the beacon things.
4. then the relay things

Or whatever.

There are some GUI changes to go along with the new error reporting mechanism; both relays and discovery now show as "3/4" type indicators (working / total) with the local discovery things just being two of those services and showing their potential errors in the hover...

Some things are unsolved and need fixing:
- [x] /rest/system/discovery cache contents and "hint" posting. Not currently easily accessible. Do we need this functionality at all? Who uses it?
- [x] stfinddevice needs fixing for the new types
- [x] the tests should probably pass
- [x] verify that relaying works and doesn't get stuck in the initial 10 minute delay thing
